candidates.definition: Relations classified by the specific number of entities they connect or relate together

positive_examples: Marriage is a binary relation between two people
The function f(x,y,z) defines a ternary relation among three variables
A quaternary predicate relates exactly four distinct arguments
This quintary operation requires five input parameters
Variable arity functions can take any number of arguments
The relation's arity determines how many entities it can connect
negative_examples: The similarity between cats and dogs is strong
John has a meaningful relationship with his sister
These two concepts are closely related in meaning
The connection between cause and effect is important
The association between smoking and cancer is well-established
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: SpatialRelation, TemporalRelation, CausalRelation, EquivalenceRelation

candidates.definition: Relations involving fundamental metaphysical connections like causation, dependence, constitution, and part-whole structures.

positive_examples: The mind supervenes on the brain, so no mental change can occur without physical change.
If the butterfly hadn't flapped its wings, the hurricane wouldn't have formed.
The software process is constituted by the underlying hardware computations.
The wheel is part of the bicycle, which enables its function.
Higher-level economic patterns are realized by individual market transactions.
The explosion caused the building to collapse through structural failure.
negative_examples: John is taller than Mary by six inches.
The red car is located next to the blue house.
Shakespeare wrote Hamlet in the early 1600s.
The population of Tokyo is greater than that of London.
This apple tastes sweeter than that orange.
The meeting is scheduled for 3 PM tomorrow.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: SpatialRelation, TemporalRelation, QuantitativeRelation, SocialRelation

candidates.definition: Relations defined by mathematical or logical properties and constraints on their argument structures.

positive_examples: The function maps each input to exactly one output value.
This probability distribution assigns likelihood values to all possible outcomes.
The economic indicator converts national currencies using purchasing power parity.
The partial function is undefined for certain input combinations.
Each student ID corresponds to at most one enrolled student.
The relation satisfies the mathematical property of being single-valued.
negative_examples: My sister is taller than my brother.
The book is on the table next to the lamp.
Sarah works for the marketing department.
The red car belongs to my neighbor.
This painting was created by Van Gogh.
The meeting occurs every Tuesday at noon.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not to be confused with: SpatialRelation, TemporalRelation, SocialRelation, CausalRelation, PhysicalRelation
